trans-unit.source: Elastic database tools glossary
trans-unit.target: Elastic database tools glossary

trans-unit.source: Explanation of terms used for elastic database tools
trans-unit.target: Explanation of terms used for elastic database tools

trans-unit.source: Elastic Database tools glossary
trans-unit.target: Elastic Database tools glossary

trans-unit.source: The following terms are defined for the Elastic Database tools, a feature of Azure SQL Database.
trans-unit.target: The following terms are defined for the Elastic Database tools, a feature of Azure SQL Database.

trans-unit.source: The tools include the client library, the split-merge tool, elastic pools, and queries.
trans-unit.target: The tools include the client library, the split-merge tool, elastic pools, and queries.

trans-unit.source: ![Elastic Scale terms][1]
trans-unit.target: ![Elastic Scale terms][1]

trans-unit.source: **Database**: An Azure SQL database.
trans-unit.target: **Database**: An Azure SQL database.

trans-unit.source: **Data dependent routing**: The functionality that enables an application to connect to a shard given a specific sharding key.
trans-unit.target: **Data dependent routing**: The functionality that enables an application to connect to a shard given a specific sharding key.

trans-unit.source: Compare to **Multi-Shard Query**.
trans-unit.target: Compare to **Multi-Shard Query**.

trans-unit.source: **Global shard map**: The map between sharding keys and their respective shards within a **shard set**.
trans-unit.target: **Global shard map**: The map between sharding keys and their respective shards within a **shard set**.

trans-unit.source: The global shard map is stored in the **shard map manager**.
trans-unit.target: The global shard map is stored in the **shard map manager**.

trans-unit.source: Compare to **local shard map**.
trans-unit.target: Compare to **local shard map**.

trans-unit.source: **List shard map**: A shard map in which sharding keys are mapped individually.
trans-unit.target: **List shard map**: A shard map in which sharding keys are mapped individually.

trans-unit.source: Compare to **Range Shard Map**.
trans-unit.target: Compare to **Range Shard Map**.

trans-unit.source: **Local shard map**: Stored on a shard, the local shard map contains mappings for the shardlets that reside on the shard.
trans-unit.target: **Local shard map**: Stored on a shard, the local shard map contains mappings for the shardlets that reside on the shard.

trans-unit.source: **Multi-shard query**: The ability to issue a query against multiple shards; results sets are returned using UNION ALL semantics (also known as “fan-out query”).
trans-unit.target: **Multi-shard query**: The ability to issue a query against multiple shards; results sets are returned using UNION ALL semantics (also known as “fan-out query”).

trans-unit.source: Compare to **data dependent routing**.
trans-unit.target: Compare to **data dependent routing**.

trans-unit.source: **Range shard map**: A shard map in which the shard distribution strategy is based on multiple ranges of contiguous values.
trans-unit.target: **Range shard map**: A shard map in which the shard distribution strategy is based on multiple ranges of contiguous values.

trans-unit.source: **Reference tables**: Tables that are not sharded but are replicated across shards.
trans-unit.target: **Reference tables**: Tables that are not sharded but are replicated across shards.

trans-unit.source: For example, zip codes can be stored in a reference table.
trans-unit.target: For example, zip codes can be stored in a reference table.

trans-unit.source: **Shard**: An Azure SQL database that stores data from a sharded data set.
trans-unit.target: **Shard**: An Azure SQL database that stores data from a sharded data set.

trans-unit.source: **Shard elasticity**: The ability to perform both **horizontal scaling** and **vertical scaling**.
trans-unit.target: **Shard elasticity**: The ability to perform both **horizontal scaling** and **vertical scaling**.

trans-unit.source: **Sharded tables**: Tables that are sharded, i.e., whose data is distributed across shards based on their sharding key values.
trans-unit.target: **Sharded tables**: Tables that are sharded, i.e., whose data is distributed across shards based on their sharding key values.

trans-unit.source: **Sharding key**: A column value that determines how data is distributed across shards.
trans-unit.target: **Sharding key**: A column value that determines how data is distributed across shards.

trans-unit.source: The value type can be one of the following: **int**, **bigint**, **varbinary**, or **uniqueidentifier**.
trans-unit.target: The value type can be one of the following: **int**, **bigint**, **varbinary**, or **uniqueidentifier**.

trans-unit.source: **Shard set**: The collection of shards that are attributed to the same shard map in the shard map manager.
trans-unit.target: **Shard set**: The collection of shards that are attributed to the same shard map in the shard map manager.

trans-unit.source: **Shardlet**: All of the data associated with a single value of a sharding key on a shard.
trans-unit.target: **Shardlet**: All of the data associated with a single value of a sharding key on a shard.

trans-unit.source: A shardlet is the smallest unit of data movement possible when redistributing sharded tables.
trans-unit.target: A shardlet is the smallest unit of data movement possible when redistributing sharded tables.

trans-unit.source: **Shard map**: The set of mappings between sharding keys and their respective shards.
trans-unit.target: **Shard map**: The set of mappings between sharding keys and their respective shards.

trans-unit.source: **Shard map manager**: A management object and data store that contains the shard map(s), shard locations, and mappings for one or more shard sets.
trans-unit.target: **Shard map manager**: A management object and data store that contains the shard map(s), shard locations, and mappings for one or more shard sets.

trans-unit.source: ![Mappings][2]
trans-unit.target: ![Mappings][2]

trans-unit.source: Verbs
trans-unit.target: Verbs

trans-unit.source: **Horizontal scaling**: The act of scaling out (or in) a collection of shards by adding or removing shards to a shard map, as shown below.
trans-unit.target: **Horizontal scaling**: The act of scaling out (or in) a collection of shards by adding or removing shards to a shard map, as shown below.

trans-unit.source: ![Horizontal and vertical scaling][3]
trans-unit.target: ![Horizontal and vertical scaling][3]

trans-unit.source: **Merge**: The act of moving shardlets from two shards to one shard and updating the shard map accordingly.
trans-unit.target: **Merge**: The act of moving shardlets from two shards to one shard and updating the shard map accordingly.

trans-unit.source: **Shardlet move**: The act of moving a single shardlet to a different shard.
trans-unit.target: **Shardlet move**: The act of moving a single shardlet to a different shard.

trans-unit.source: **Shard**: The act of horizontally partitioning identically structured data across multiple databases based on a sharding key.
trans-unit.target: **Shard**: The act of horizontally partitioning identically structured data across multiple databases based on a sharding key.

trans-unit.source: **Split**: The act of moving several shardlets from one shard to another (typically new) shard.
trans-unit.target: **Split**: The act of moving several shardlets from one shard to another (typically new) shard.

trans-unit.source: A sharding key is provided by the user as the split point.
trans-unit.target: A sharding key is provided by the user as the split point.

trans-unit.source: **Vertical Scaling**: The act of scaling up (or down) the performance level of an individual shard.
trans-unit.target: **Vertical Scaling**: The act of scaling up (or down) the performance level of an individual shard.

trans-unit.source: For example, changing a shard from Standard to Premium (which results in more computing resources).
trans-unit.target: For example, changing a shard from Standard to Premium (which results in more computing resources).
